description: A woman around 60 to 70 years old

npcTexts: I moved here about 5 years ago.
Back then it was quiet, not many people around.
Things are fine, except for strange noises some nights.
I take sewing jobs, people bring clothes and pick them up after a few days.
I usually work mornings, rest in the afternoon, then read or drink tea in the evening.
It’s enough to live.
No, I just make small talk.
Everyone here is busy, nobody cares much about others.
No, never had one.
Pets need care, but I prefer quiet.
So my room is always empty.
Alright, take care at night.
More than 6 years now.
Back then, few rooms had lights at night.
Now it’s busier, but I still close my door early.
Still sewing, but fewer customers.
I listen to the radio at night to feel less lonely.
Sometimes I sleep early, sometimes stay up late sewing.
I know some faces, some stop by to chat.
I don’t recall names, just clothes or voices.
People come and go, always changing.
Never had pets.
I’m too old to care for them.
So my room is always empty.
Watch your back tonight, the wind is strong.
So long… I don’t know anymore.
Sometimes I recall each day, sometimes it all blends into one endless night.
Ahh… my head hurts, my eyes… my eyes…
I still sew… but not just clothes.
I like stitching together torn things. Sometimes fabric, sometimes… other things.
The sound of the needle piercing layers is soothing.
Of course, I know everyone. They all come to my room eventually.
They may not remember, but I recall each person’s scent. Especially when they stand very close.
I keep some… but they no longer look the same.
They stay silent, obedient… and never leave.
Do you want to meet them?
Next time… don’t rush away. I’ll show you what I just stitched.
I’ve been here since before this house was built.
These walls know me, every brick has drunk warm blood.
Time is a trick. This place doesn’t change, only people come and go.
I stitch layers of skin so they fit tight, no gaps.
Sometimes it’s the guest’s skin, sometimes my own.
The needle knows the way, I only follow.
They’re all here… inside me.
They don’t talk much anymore, but I hear them when night falls.
You’ll understand, once the door closes.
Yes… but they’re not the same anymore.
They crawl on the floor, scratching… only quiet when I touch them.
You’ll see them when the lights go out.
Stay… so I don’t have to search anymore.
